t: Job 34
Furthermore*p Elihu answered and said,
Hear*p my words, O ye wise men; and give ear unto me, ye that have knowledge.
For*p the ear trieth words, as the mouth tasteth meat.
Let*p us choose to us judgment: let us know among ourselves what is good.
For*p Job hath said, I am righteous: and God hath taken away my judgment.
Should*p I lie against my right? my wound is incurable without transgression.
What*p man is like Job, who drinketh up scorning like water?
Which*p goeth in company with the workers of iniquity, and walketh with wicked men.
For*p he hath said, It profiteth a man nothing that he should delight himself with God.
Therefore*p hearken unto me, ye men of understanding: far be it from God, that he should do wickedness; and from the Almighty, that he should commit iniquity.
For*p the work of a man shall he render unto him, and cause every man to find according to his ways.
Yea,*p surely God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almighty pervert judgment.
Who*p hath given him a charge over the earth? or who hath disposed the whole world?
If*p he set his heart upon man, if he gather unto himself his spirit and his breath;
All*p flesh shall perish together, and man shall turn again unto dust.
If*p now thou hast understanding, hear this: hearken to the voice of my words.
Shall*p even he that hateth right govern? and wilt thou condemn him that is most just?
Is*p it fit to say to a king, Thou art wicked? and to princes, Ye are ungodly?
How*p much less to him that accepteth not the persons of princes, nor regardeth the rich more than the poor? for they all are the work of his hands.
In*p a moment shall they die, and the people shall be troubled at midnight, and pass away: and the mighty shall be taken away without hand.
For*p his eyes are upon the ways of man, and he seeth all his goings.
There*p is no darkness, nor shadow of death, where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
For*p he will not lay upon man more than right; that he should enter into judgment with God.
He*p shall break in pieces mighty men without number, and set others in their stead.
Therefore*p he knoweth their works, and he overturneth them in the night, so that they are destroyed.
He*p striketh them as wicked men in the open sight of others;
Because*p they turned back from him, and would not consider any of his ways:
So*p that they cause the cry of the poor to come unto him, and he heareth the cry of the afflicted.
When*p he giveth quietness, who then can make trouble? and when he hideth his face, who then can behold him? whether it be done against a nation, or against a man only:
That*p the hypocrite reign not, lest the people be ensnared.
Surely*p it is meet to be said unto God, I have borne chastisement, I will not offend any more:
That*p which I see not teach thou me: if I have done iniquity, I will do no more.
Should*p it be according to thy mind? he will recompense it, whether thou refuse, or whether thou choose; and not I: therefore speak what thou knowest.
Let*p men of understanding tell me, and let a wise man hearken unto me.
Job*p hath spoken without knowledge, and his words were without wisdom.
My*p desire is that Job may be tried unto the end because of his answers for wicked men.
For*p he addeth rebellion unto his sin, he clappeth his hands among us, and multiplieth his words against God.
